Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my telemarketing dashboard—my break was scheduled in five minutes, but the call queue was empty, and my supervisor had just said we could take breaks early if things stayed slow. I felt a rare sense of freedom, a small perk in an otherwise rigid job. I decided to use the time to drop off my mail-in ballot at the polling station down the street. When I arrived, the poll worker inspected my envelope and frowned. “The signature is smudged. Could you please re-sign it? Otherwise, your vote might not count.” I hesitated, pen in hand. My telemarketer training drilled into me the importance of following company schedules, even if supervisors were lenient. But as a voter, I knew I had to follow every instruction from election officials to ensure my ballot was valid. My mind raced—should I risk being late returning from break, or ignore the poll worker’s request and hope my vote would still count? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my loyalty, and I stood there, torn, unable to move.
